td.p: Thomson, John. Journal, Mackenzie River, 1800-1802. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0021

div.p: and took 12 on Credit[.] Paid him 2 skins for having feed La Beccasse[.] The hunter brought 23 hares[.]

Saturday the 22d[.] Snowed again last night[.] [O]n[e] of the y Men vissited the Snares & took 6 hares – the other made himself Snow shoes[.] The Little Chiefs brother in law came & paid 14 Skins of Credits, gave him 4 Skins on Credit, & the value of 4 skins, for having employed him since the fall running after his Countrymen[.]

Monday the 2[4]th[.] Early in the morning a young man came for Tobacco Vermillion & powder, for the Big Chief sent him 2 foot of Tobc & a little vermillion – a short time after he arrived along with 8 Men & a Boy, gave them drams & pieces of Tobacco[.] The Chief made several long speeches all of which contained a great many excuses for not having brought more skins &c – altho he says he had not been a moment Idle, but their Lands are now so Barren that there is no more Beavers to be found, what few there was they have already destroyed &c &c[.] Received 80 Skins Credits, & Traded 20 skins, 6 skins Dry Meat[,] 8 of Pounded, 4 of Grease, ½ of Beaver tails[,] 1 of castoreum & 6 cascamisks[.] The Chief says that we are not Built in the proper place, as he intended that the Fort should have been further down about half a Days march, at a much more convenient place, where there is a River quite close out of which we might take a sufficient quantity of Fish, every spring & Fall to feed all hands[.] It is certainly very vexing, that the Indians we found here last Fall, would not point out that place to us, altho I repeatedly asked them if they were acquainted with the place appointed by the Big Chief for the Fort, but they positively assured me that this & no other was the place appoint[ed] for if we went further down we would not find any wood fit for Building &c[.] The y Men brought 20 hares[.]
